info.title: Enabling hotplugging for network bond ports

abstract.para: In some network environments (such as High Availability), you might need to replace a bond port interface with a new one, for example, if a network device is constantly failing. However, before you can replace the interface you must configure the networking setup to recognize when a new device is added.

procedure.title: Enabling hotplugging for network bond ports

step.para: Check that the bond ports are configured with STARTMODE=hotplug and BOOTPROTO=none. This should be the default setting. For example, in /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-eth0:

callout.para: BOOTPROTO=none uses the ethtool options (when provided), but does not set up the link on ifup eth0 because the bond port interface is controlled by the bond device.
STARTMODE=hotplug allows the bond port interface to join the bond automatically when it is available.

step.para: Run the command hwinfo --netcard and make a note of the SysFS BusID.

In /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules, change the value of KERNELS to match the SysFS BusID from the previous step. This configures the udev rules to match the device by bus ID instead of by MAC address, allowing the bond to detect a new device in the same slot but with a different MAC address. For example:
step.screen: SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", KERNELS=="0000:00:19.0", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"

topic.para: At boot time, network.service does not wait for the hotplug bond ports, but for the bond to become ready, which requires at least one available bond port. When one of the bond port interfaces is removed from the system, the kernel removes it from the bond automatically. When a new card is added to the system, udev uses the bus-based persistent name rule to rename the card to the name of the bond port, and calls ifup for it. The ifup call automatically joins the new card into the bond.
